captions.text:
And so, we get around to Death Stranding 2: 
On the Beach. Or to use the more apt title,

Death Stranding 2: On the Skip Cutscene Button. 
Oh, don&#39;t give me that look, Hideo Kojima. You

know I like you, really, and think the video 
game industry is a more interesting place

with you in it, in the way a summer vacation 
becomes a lot more interesting when a giant,

tuberculotic narwhal washes up on the 
beach wearing a t-shirt for a popular J-pop

idol group. I don&#39;t want to go into spoilers 
too early, so let me hint at what to expect

using the &quot;two truths and a lie&quot; technique. Two 
of the following appear in Death Stranding 2:

A tightly choreographed, close-quarters kung fu 
fight in a kitchen with a pizza chef. A gunfight

in a car park against a schoolgirl wearing a giant 
anime character head. And a shirtless guitar duel

that ends with one of the participants being 
eaten by a giant, slimy baby. But as always,

the really fun part of Hideo Kojima games is 
not that they&#39;re complete fucking nonsense,

it&#39;s the knowledge that they make perfect sense 
to Hideo Kojima. And he&#39;s really fucking happy to

explain how. One day, I just want to sit in on 
one of his pitch meetings. I imagine there&#39;s a

lot of nodding and smiling and urgent glances 
to the cabinet with the tranquillizer gun.

Anyway, here&#39;s the plot: Norman Reedus and 
his magic fetus have gone into hiding after

the events of the first game and are living his 
best grumpy single dad life with the now slightly

larger magic fetus until that moony tart with 
the weird umbrella shows up again and says, &quot;Hey,

great job connecting up all of America and that, 
but we&#39;ve just realized, in the grand tradition

of being Americans, we forgot that other countries 
exist. I assume I&#39;m American, anyway; my accent&#39;s

all over the fucking place.&quot; So, after making some 
inroads to Mexico, we decide the logical next step

is to connect up all of Australia, appropriately 
enough. You know. Appropriate because of &quot;On the

Beach.&quot; It&#39;s a reference to On the Beach, the 
1957 Nevil Shute novel about people in Australia

dealing with a global apocalypse. No? Oh, dear. 
It&#39;s okay, Mr. Kojima, sir. I understood your

clever reference; should I tell everyone else to 
report to detention? Luckily, a magic portal to

Australia appears in Mexico, conjured from the 
mysterious fantasy realm where all the really

contrived things live, and Norman Reedus can get 
to work delivering shit to good ol&#39; Down Under.

So, there are two recurring issues with Kojima&#39;s 
writing, neither of which he&#39;s done much to fix:

Firstly, really weird emotional tone. All 
the characters are to relatable human emotion

what the main characters in the Dawn of the 
Dead remake were to that one gun shop owner

dude stuck on the roof across the parking lot. 
There are moments in the plot early on that I

found genuinely moving and affecting, especially 
as a father, and then one fucking cutscene later,

we&#39;re being introduced to Dollman, the man who is 
a doll. To join our established friends Heartman,

the man with a weird heart, and Deadman, the 
man who gets really poor radio reception.

And Kojima&#39;s other main issue is dialogue. 
His characters don&#39;t talk with each other;

they talk AT each other. Very little verbal 
sparring, or back-and-forth, or chemistry,

just mostly clunky exposition. &quot;Hey, I&#39;m 
going to the shops, you want anything?&quot; &quot;Yeah,

could you get me a Twix?&quot; That&#39;s how normal people 
talk. Here&#39;s how that would go down in a Kojima

game. &quot;Yahtzee, I&#39;ve noticed you&#39;re running low 
on energy. Have you considered eating a Twix? It&#39;s

a unique combination of chocolate, caramel, 
and biscuit that provides all the necessary

sugars and nutrients to temporarily boost your 
stamina. What&#39;s more, you can easily acquire

one from many retail outlets. But first, I must 
also explain to you the concept of Snickers.&quot;

But again, we expect this from Hideo, and it&#39;s 
why we love him; the really disappointing thing

about Death Stranding 2 is that it hasn&#39;t 
really evolved much since the first game.

It&#39;s hitting a lot of the same beats. You&#39;re 
linking up Australia instead of America,

you&#39;re best friends with a doll who is 
a man now, but not much has changed in

the core gameplay. I&#39;d say there&#39;s a bit more 
emphasis on combat this time, and instead of

the odd boss battle in dreamworld against Mads 
Mikkelsen, the campaign is broken up with the

odd boss battle in dreamworld against a bloke 
dressed like Solid Snake with a distractingly

big nose. Besides that, the core mechanic is 
still the simple act of getting yourself to

places when the terrain is uneven and you&#39;ve 
got nine toaster ovens strapped to your back,

and in the moments when you are trudging across 
the scenery, it&#39;s still as weirdly compelling

and contemplative as before as you marvel 
at your smallness against the majesty of the

wilderness and the strength of Norman Reedus&#39; 
lower spine. It&#39;s just all the fiddling about

in between that annoys me; the moment-to-moment 
interfacing has a serious efficiency problem.

I don&#39;t like that I can&#39;t stealth kill dudes 
unless I go out of my way to equip my magic

bit of string, which means sticking my hand in 
the radial menu that looks like a mechanical

wasp&#39;s nest put together by Jigsaw. Where with 
the slightest mis-press, I might accidentally

drop my gun and equip Norman Reedus&#39; ability to 
do wee wees instead. I also shouldn&#39;t have to

click through five information screens and 
skip three mini-cutscenes just to complete

a delivery mission. Practically, the game&#39;s 
second core mechanic is skipping cutscenes.

If I want Norman Reedus to have a shower, I 
have to skip the cutscene where he gets up,

skip the cutscene where he turns the 
tap, skip the cutscene where he showers,

and skip the cutscene of him sitting down 
again. Then, I make him eat a bug and skip

the cutscene for that and then skip the cutscene 
of him having a lovely can of drink as well. Not

Monster Energy Drink this time; guess that 
contract didn&#39;t get renewed. Probably after

the Monster people found out that 90% of their 
product&#39;s screen time was taking place after it

had passed through Norman Reedus&#39; kidneys. The 
other thing on the list of common Hideo Kojima

game issues is that he always gives us way too 
much shit to achieve relatively simple tasks.

Metal Gear Solid 4 didn&#39;t need nine different 
kinds of porn mag to distract guards, and one

of the big finale quests in Death Stranding 2 is 
just to get from one end of the map to the other,

saying, &quot;Ooh, be prepared for anything; this 
will be your toughest challenge yet,&quot; but all

I had to do was drive slowly around the coast, 
giving a wide berth to all the killer robots,

and the only preparation needed in the end 
was to load up on fucking audiobooks. Still,

they were jolly interesting audiobooks, and I 
appreciate Death Stranding 2 for giving me a

chance to catch up on them. It&#39;s not a game I find 
unenjoyable, is the point, but at the same time,

there&#39;s something about Death Stranding that&#39;s 
always given me the ick. Bug eating aside,

part of it&#39;s that the characters all occupy a 
sort of personality uncanny valley that&#39;s heard

of emotions but isn&#39;t sure it wants anything 
to do with them. But the big part of it is

the weird fixation on Norman Reedus&#39; bodily 
functions and perving on him in the shower.

Just feels like if you swapped out Norman Reedus 
for, say, an anime schoolgirl, the game would be

indistinguishable from one of those weird Japanese 
fetish games. Hey, no judgement. Some people are

into watching girls go wee wee in the shower and 
then strapping a six-foot wardrobe to their backs.
